structured_notes_xml:
<structured_notes>
    <project_name>Fitness application discussion</project_name>
    <company_overview>Not specified</company_overview>
    <attendees>
        <attendee>Sarah (PM)</attendee>
        <attendee>Mike (Tech Lead)</attendee>
        <attendee>Jessica (Designer)</attendee>
        <attendee>Tom (Marketing)</attendee>
    </attendees>
    <meeting_date>January 15, 2025</meeting_date>
    <meeting_objective>To brainstorm and discuss ideas for a new beginner-friendly fitness app, including features, monetization, tech stack, and timeline.</meeting_objective>
    <key_discussion_points>
        <point>Targeting beginners in fitness who find traditional apps overwhelming, focusing on simplicity and encouragement.</point>
        <point>Key features: workout tracking, pre-made workout plans, exercise demonstrations (via images/GIFs or partnerships), meal photo tracking with AI analysis, progress visualization, basic social sharing, customizable notifications, and integrations with Apple Health and Google Fit.</point>
        <point>Monetization via freemium model: basic features free, premium subscription ($9.99/month) for advanced plans, analytics, and personalized features.</point>
        <point>Tech stack: React Native for mobile, Node.js backend with PostgreSQL, AWS for hosting (EC2, S3, RDS), using APIs like Clarifai for food recognition.</point>
        <point>Target audience: 25-45 year olds, more women, who want to get healthier but are intimidated by gyms and complex apps.</point>
        <point>Timeline: 6-8 months to launch MVP, including development, testing, and polish.</point>
        <point>Value proposition: Simple, achievable fitness tracking without overwhelming data.</point>
    </key_discussion_points>
    <pain_points>
        <pain_point>Competing with well-resourced companies like Apple and existing apps (e.g., MyFitnessPal).</pain_point>
        <pain_point>Complexity and tedium of nutrition tracking; need for simplicity.</pain_point>
        <pain_point>High costs of video hosting for exercise demos.</pain_point>
        <pain_point>Risks of social features requiring moderation and privacy controls.</pain_point>
        <pain_point>Accuracy concerns with AI for food recognition.</pain_point>
        <pain_point>Potential for push notifications to be annoying if not customizable.</pain_point>
    </pain_points>
    <requirements>
        <requirement>Workout tracking with logging of exercises, reps, and sets.</requirement>
        <requirement>Pre-made beginner workout plans and exercise demonstrations.</requirement>
        <requirement>Meal photo tracking with AI analysis and gamification (e.g., badges).</requirement>
        <requirement>Progress visualization with before/after photos, weight tracking, and journey maps.</requirement>
        <requirement>Basic social features for private sharing of progress.</requirement>
        <requirement>Customizable reminders and notifications.</requirement>
        <requirement>Integrations with Apple Health and Google Fit.</requirement>
        <requirement>Freemium model with premium features like advanced analytics and unlimited plans.</requirement>
    </requirements>
    <decisions_made>
        <decision>Focus on beginner-friendly app with simplicity as core value.</decision>
        <decision>Adopt freemium monetization with $9.99/month premium subscription.</decision>
        <decision>Use React Native for mobile, Node.js backend, PostgreSQL database, and AWS hosting.</decision>
        <decision>Integrate existing APIs for AI food recognition (e.g., Clarifai).</decision>
        <decision>Target audience: 25-45 year olds, primarily women intimidated by fitness.</decision>
        <decision>Timeline: 6-8 months for MVP launch.</decision>
        <decision>Mobile-first approach, no web version initially.</decision>
    </decisions_made>
    <action_items>
        <action_item>Sarah to create a formal Product Requirements Document (PRD) based on the discussion and review it next week.</action_item>
    </action_items>
    <technical_constraints>
        <constraint>Video hosting is expensive; start with images/GIFs or partnerships for demos.</constraint>
        <constraint>AI for food recognition may not be perfectly accurate; rely on existing APIs.</constraint>
        <constraint>Development costs estimated at $300K-$400K for 6 months with 4-5 people; ongoing hosting/API costs $2K-$5K/month.</constraint>
        <constraint>Need to manage infrastructure for image storage and backend scalability.</constraint>
    </technical_constraints>
    <stakeholders>
        <stakeholder>Sarah (PM)</stakeholder>
        <stakeholder>Mike (Tech Lead)</stakeholder>
        <stakeholder>Jessica (Designer)</stakeholder>
        <stakeholder>Tom (Marketing)</stakeholder>
    </stakeholders>
</structured_notes>
